REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS ■j Report of the State Auditor STATE OF NEBRASKA, AUDITORS OFFICE, Lincoln. To His Excellency, Hon. John H. Morehead Governor of Nebraska. Dear Sir:— Complying with the laws of this state relating to this department I am submitting herewith my biennial report for the period from No - vember 30th, 1914, to December 1st, 1916. In connection herewith you will find tabulated statements giving detailed reports of the re - ceipts and expenditures during this period, as well as the present financial condition of the various governmental departments supported by the state. I am particularly pleased to direct your attention to the splendid con - dition of the state's finances at this time, and to the further fact that the affairs are being so managed that the incoming session of the legislature will be called upon to make comparatively few if any de - ficiency appropriations. The following will show the balance on hand in all funds on Novem - ber 30th, 1914, the aggregate income from all sources during the past biennium, the payments made, and the balance on hand November 30th, 1916: Balance on hand, Nov. 30, 1914 S 746,108.92 Of the work in the Auditor's office in particular I beg to offer the following: The Bond Department The past biennium this department of the auditor's office has ap - proved 581 bond issues, and registered 11,106 bonds aggregating $7,055, - 639.08, as compared to 482 issues during the previous biennium when 8,776 bonds were registered aggregating $4,492,831.98. In addition to those approved approximately fifty issues have been rejected aggre - gating nearly $2,000,000.00, two rejected issues from Douglas county alone amounting to $1,700,000.00. Receipts during biennium 'ayrr.ents during biennium 14,12 20,267.61— $14,866,376.53 13,577,702.14 14,866,376.53 13,577,702.14 Balance November 30, 1916 $ 1,288,674.39

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 6 I This department is growing very rapidly and I believe it should eventually be made self-sustaining by charging a small fee for passing on the histories and registering each bond. Trust Companies There are now sixteen trust companies in Nebraska operating under the supervision of the Auditor, and these, according to their last re - port, had resources aggregating $5,350,548.94. Omaha Water District The last legislature added to the work of the Auditor's office by requiring it to audit once each year the books and affairs of the Metro - politan Water District of Omaha. This was done for the first time the past year. County Treasurer Examinations During the past two years we have been able to make an exam - ination of each county treasury in the state three times, and part of them a fourth. Frequent examinations are an advantage to both the state and county, and in most cases the county treasurers welcome them. During 1913 and 1914 most of the county treasurers were ex - amined twice, and prior to that period they were examined once in twenty-two months. An additional examiner was asked for from the legislature by former auditors that the examinations might be made once a year, but without this extra examiner we have been able to complete three examinations in two years. Other Examinations Frequently this department is asked to provide an examiner to check other county offices than the treasurer's, but there is no pro - vision for this. I believe it would therefore be well for the legislature to provide that the state auditor may in the future comply with these requests. A per diem charge could be fixed by the legislature for the work, and a special examiner — should the regular force be unable to handle it — could be designated to conduct the examination, to be paid out of the fees collected from the county. This might result in the establishment by a future legislature of a regular examiner to handle this work, or if it proves there are not sufficient calls for his services the plan could be abandoned. Claims Handled. The foregoing may be designated special activities in connection with the auditor's office. In addition thereto is the regular work, which has included the passing on claims and issuing warrants aggregating $10,464,282.97 the past bienmum.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS Old Insane Accounts At the close of the biennium two years ago there were outstanding on these accounts a total of $78,982.95. The collections since have amounted to $32,197.19, leaving a balance outstanding on December 1st, 1916, of $46,785.78. Suits were commenced against Gage and Stanton counties to re - cover the amounts due from them, and the cases were referred by the supreme court to a referee, who found for the state in each case. The court has not as yet reviewed his findings, however, but should it sustain the same the collection of the amounts still due from the ether counties will be comparatively easy. Consolidation of Departments In defining the duties of the State Auditor Section 5545 of Article 3 of the Statutes provides in the fourth provision that he shall report to the governor "such plans as he may deem expedient • • • for lessen - ing the public expense, for using the public money to the best advan - tage, for promoting frugality and economy in public offices * • • and for securing uniformity and efficiency in the levying and collecting of taxes." Accordingly I submit the following based upon an obser - vation of conditions in connection therewith: Commissioner of Public Lands and Buildings: It is my belief that the interests of the taxpayers of the state would best be served by a consolidation of the department of the com - missioner of public lands and buildings with that of the state audi - tor. At the time the board of commissioners for state institutions was created by the adoption of a constitutional amendment in 1912 a large part of the work of the commissioner of public lands and buildings was taken over by the board. He is still the custodian of the records pertaining to Nebraska's educational lands and funds, but these could be filed with one department as well as another. These matte/s are under the supervision of the board of educational lands and funds, a constitutional board, and the auditor could be substituted on this board for the commissioner of public lands and buildings. The consolidation would result in a large saving annually to the state, and simplify the keeping of the records. To effect the consolidation would require approximately four years. The departments are executive, created by the constitution. It would be necessary, therefore, for the incoming legislature to submit to the people to be voted on at the general election in 1918 a proposed constitu - tional amendment combining the two departments. If the amendment should be adopted by the people the 1919 session of the legislature would be called upon to revise the laws of the state affecting the two departments. As my term of public service will have expired prior to the time the consolidation could be brought about, it cannot bs assert - ed that I have a personal interest in the matter.

8 REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS The Printing Bureau The printing bureau, as it has been handled for years past, has not given satisfaction. It has been the custom for the deputy commis - sioner to give about one-half his time to the work. The salary is $1,500 per annum. I believe the bureau should be consolidated with the secre - tary of state's department, or with this department. A printing clerk could be provided, as the corporation clerk is now provided for in the secretary of state's office to handle the corporation records and affairs or as the bond clerk is provided for in this department, to handle the bond work. Taxation Matters It cose the various counties of this state a total of $267,600.00 to make the assessment in 1916, or an average cost per county of $2,865.55. Of this sum $180,100.00 was paid local assessors, $47,000 to county as - sessors and $40,500.00 for books, blanks, extra help, etc. And yet the work is not satisfactory, but taxation problems are as old as the pro - verbial "Heck's pup," and they will probably confront generations yet unborn. The plans adopted by Arkansas and Oklahoma have much to commend, however, and I believe are worthy of consideration. In those states the assessments are made almost entirely by the county assessor, who visits the various townships on given days and the people call on him to list their property, as they call at the county treasurer's office to pay their taxes in Nebraska. The expense under this plan is ma - terially reduced, and a more uniform valuation is placed on the va - rious forms of property. Our educational institutions should be well provided for in the way of appropriations, but it is doubtful if the plan of appropriating indefi - nite sums by a mill levy or a fractional mill levy is the best from the public standpoint. While the problem of equalizing values between counties was confronting the state board of equalization and assess - ment it developed that some counties objected to a raise because of the automatic increased amounts they would be called upon to pay these institutions. The present plan will, it seems to me, have a tendency to keep valuations down, although there has been a small increase from year to year. Respectfully submitted, WM. H. SMITH, December 1, 1916. State Auditor.
PART I Statistical Report of State Auditor
